question: C'mon...C'mon...
answer: Just a minute, Mr. Weldon. I think... I'm sorry. I thought that was Mr. Falco returning. Yes, I'll tell him when he comes in. I know he's been trying to reach you. That's the third time he's called today.

question: He wants me to break a leg?
answer: No, an arm, he said. I told him you were sure the item would be in Mr. Hunsecker's column in tomorrow's...

question: It isn't. I've just seen the early edition.
answer: But...

question: But what?
answer: That makes five days in a row that Mr. Hunsecker's cut you out of his column.

question: May I rent you out as an adding machine. Get me Joe Robard. Who else phoned?
answer: The renting agent and the tailor.

question: Pay the rent. Let the tailor wait.
answer: It won't leave much of a balance in the bank... Mr. Robard? Could you locate him?

question: Now, wait a minute, Joe. When I saw J.J. last night he said...
answer: I wish I could help in some way, Sidney.

question: Help me with two minutes of silence! Go home, Sally. It's late...
answer: I hate to see you like this --

question: Yes, but as a new subscriber you're under no obligation to take more than three books. And if you mail the enclosed card within ten days --
answer: Sidney, I know you by now. Don't do a dance with me...

question: You mean you don't want the extra free gift of a colorful giant map of the world???
answer: Sidney, please, dear, if you feel nervous...

question: So what'll you do if I feel nervous? You'll open your meaty, sympathetic arms...?
answer: Sid...you got me so...I don't know what...

question: You ought to be used to me by now.
answer: I'm used to you...

question: No. You think I'm a hero. I'm no hero. I'm nice to people where it pays me to be. I gotta do it too much on the outside, so don't expect me to kow-tow in my own office. I'm in a bind right now with Hunsecker so -- Every dog has his day! Lock up and leave the key. If that's for me, tear it up!
answer: Take a top coat.

question: And leave a tip in every hat-check room in town?
answer: Sidney Falco office... Oh, Miss Kay, he tried to reach you. No, he's at the barbers now. No, that's held over till the Tuesday column...

question: A close shot. Sidney has just entered the club, strolling into the vestibule near the entrance. He wears an expression of oddly unsuitable antagonism, as he looks forward...
answer: Don't you ever get messages, Eyelashes? I called you twice.

question: I've been up to here. Listen, honey, tell me something. You know Susan Hunsecker...? Has she been in? I mean lately, in the last coupla days...?
answer: I don't think so.

question: You're sure. Find out for me.
answer: Sidney, can I talk to you a minute?

question: Is Frank D'Angelo around?
answer: At the bar - Sidney...

question: That's a lollipop that, boy. The kid is only great.
answer: And with ten percent of his future, you're great, too, Frank.

question: Went over to Philly yesterday an' seen the folks...it's nice you send them the fifty a month...
answer: See my mother?

question: I only had a few hours. Thanks for the publicity spread you got the boys for the benefit tomorrow.
answer: Robard's my client. I did it for him and his club, not your boys. Frank, I think maybe you lied to me.

question: Looka, Sidney, you're my own sister's son, but where does that give you the right to call me a liar?
answer: You told me that your boy was washed up with Susie Hunsecker, didn't you?

question: Yeah, and it's the truth, to the best of my knowledge. And, frankly, I'm glad. For Steve's sake, I'm glad, not yours. I manage these boys and I got their best interests at heart. Steve shouldn't get mixed up with no bimbo at his age.
answer: You told him that?

question: Not in those exact words - you know what a temper he's got.
answer: When do these hot-headed boys of yours go on the road?

question: Coupla weeks. For eight weeks.
answer: That's a nice tour. All booked? When was Susie around here last?

question: Four five nights ago. That's how I know the romance is off. Also Steve's in a very bad mood.
answer: Listen, Frank, you'd better make sure you're telling me the truth.

question: Hi! Susie...
answer: Hello, Chico. Paul.

question: Throw a rope round this chick while I go get Steve.
answer: Full house...?

question: This is big, you know. Very big! Let's go out later, drink some firewater. With the boys. Fred can call Millie and -
answer: Steve, I'd rather you didn't say anything for a day or two...until I tell my brother...

question: His sobering reaction shows this is something important. You haven't told him yet...
answer: I'm telling him in the morning after breakfast.

question: He isn't going to like it. You sure you don't want me to be with you...?
answer: Steve, my brother isn't as bad as he's painted. He isn't perfect, but -

question: But he isn't going to like this, Susie. And he makes you nervous, not me. No, I take that back - he makes me nervous, too. But I wouldn't give him a second thought if not for you.
answer: Let's forget him and -

question: His stooge, Falco, is around - I saw him walk in. He's been spying on me for weeks, Susie.
answer: Darling, I don't care - really I don't. Sidney'd had a secret crush on me for years, but nothing we do is his business -

question: But he could be reporting back to your brother, couldn't he?
answer: Steve, dear, please forget all of this. What can it matter after tomorrow?

question: I have a message for you; I love you. May I dedicate the next number to you?...And the next, and the next. Every Sunday I'll buy you a new bonnet -
answer: If the stores are open -

question: And on Monday, I'll take it off and stroke your light brown hair and -
answer: And on Tuesday - Hasenpfeffer.

question: How do you think I realized I love you?
answer: I made you write a beautiful song...

question: No, you had me eating that Chinese food!...
answer: Can more than two enjoy this joke... Hello, Susie, I didn't expect to find you here. Where's those glossy prints you promised? Tonight's the latest I can place them -

question: Well, thanks, anyway - let's forget it. It's cold out here, Susie.
answer: Let me apologize for getting you that press spread. It's been an honor to serve you gratis.

question: Don't tell me you started a polka with Leo Bartha?
answer: No. That's what I mean - I'm being fired for what I didn't do. He came in last week on a very dull rainy night. I know who he was, but I didn't let on. He didn't take his eyes off me all night. Listening...?

question: Avidly. He was staring.
answer: Staring. Consequently, when he approached me on his way out I wasn't surprised, but I didn't let on.

question: He was writing a special Sunday piece on...?
answer: ...cigarette girls... And naturally -

question: You were thrilled to be interviewed. Were you "interviewed"?
answer: In his apartment -

question: And where was his wife?
answer: I don't know - it's a big apartment. But I wasn't interviewed. In fact, I was totally unprepared for what happened.

question: We're old friends, Chickie - quit it! A big columnist comes in this room, without his ball-and-chain and you make like a delicatessen counter! What did you think would happen in his house?
answer: But, Sidney darling, the man must be out of his mind - it was only eleven o'clock in the morning! For a moment I was so taken aback that I said anything that popped into my sleepy head. If I'm not mistaken, I even ordered the man out of his own house. He was furious and, by the time I could have put on a Tropical Island mood, I was out on the street!... That night Mr. Van Cleve calls me into his office here. He's got nothing against me, he says but he can't afford to antagonize columnists. I told him I still have Sonny at military academy, but Van Cleve's made of ice... Do you think you could do something, Sidney?

question: That's what I'm thinking, Rita. Maybe...
answer: Do you still keep your key under the mat?

question: You're touchy, Sidney - don't be so touchy...
answer: I wasn't looking for a brawl. I came to bring him a present. Wanna bite to eat? Feels like a Monday night, don't it...?

question: Not to me. Sometimes, the world feels like a cage. Then someone comes along and opens the door...and it's never Monday night again... I wish you and Steve could like each other.
answer: We stick in each others craw.

question: Yes, but why?
answer: Well, for one thing, he thinks J.J. is some kind of monster.

question: Quizzically, she studies Sidney. Don't you?
answer: He looks up sharply, Swiftly, he assumes a protesting air. Susie, your brother's one of my best friends, and -

question: I know. But someday I'd like to look into your clever mind and see what you REALLY think of him -
answer: Where do you come off to make a remark like that?

question: Who could love a man who keeps jumping through burning hoops, like a trained poodle? Do you think J.J. likes Steve...?
answer: Frankly, yes, to my surprise. He thinks he's very gifted - those boys'll go a big mile, he thinks. You feel pretty strong about this boy? Wedding bells, you mean?

question: He wants me to go on the road with them. It's an eight month tour, all the way to Oregon...
answer: The news has considerable impact on him. But he hides it, saying lightly: Well, congratulations. But don't go just for the ride! Or didn't you accept the proposal?

question: I'm going to discuss it with J.J. in the morning. It's given me a big lift to know that some people want me for myself, not just because I'm my brother's sister.
answer: Chickie, I'll have to laugh at that - an attractive girl like you...!

question: I hope that J.J. really likes Steve, that it isn't an act.
answer: Why should he put on an act? Your brother has told PRESIDENTS where to go and what to do!

question: The act would be for my sake, not Steve's...
answer: Wait for me. I'll be right back.

question: Hearing him, Susan turns back. Sidney walks into shot to join her.
answer: It's not my nature, Susie, but I'll talk to you like an uncle...

question: The Twenty One Club. Jimmy! This is a coincidence. I am just going -
answer: Yeah. A coincidence you should run into the very man you've been ducking all week! This is my press agent, Joan.

question: I tried to reach you twice -
answer: What do you do for that hundred a week. Fall out of bed?

question: Jimmy, I'm on my way inside right now to talk to Hunsecker. I can promise you -
answer: Joan, call a cop! We'll arrest this kid for larceny!

question: Listen, when your band was playing at Roseland -
answer: That was two months ago. Take your hand out of my pocket, thief! Why? It's a dirty job, but I pay clean money for it, don't I?

question: No more you don't! What is this - You're showing off for her? They're supposed to hear you in Korea?
answer: He's intuitive - he knows he's getting fired!

question: If you're funny, James, I'm a pretzel! Drop dead!
answer: It was nice knowing you, Sidney. Not cheap - but nice. Happy unemployment insurance.

question: How are you tonight, Mr. Falco?
answer: Is "he" inside?

question: But of course...
answer: Alone or surrounded?

question: Honey, get me Mr. Hunsecker. So it isn't Long Distance. J.J.? It's me -- J.J., it's Sidney. Can you come outside for one minute?
answer: Can I come out? No.

question: I have to talk to you, alone, J.J., that's why.
answer: You had something to do for me - you didn't do it.

question: Can I come in for a minute?
answer: No. You're dead, son - get yourself buried! From Sidney's viewpoint. Hunsecker is seated at a table which is cleverly his habitual position. We see him only in semi-back view, a broad and powerful back. He is listening to a man who has paused at his table, stooping over Hunsecker to whisper in his ear. As the columnist listens, his hands play with an omni-present pad and pencil which lie on the dinner table amongst an assortment of envelopes, mimeographed sheets and a telephone. Beyond Hunsecker and the man talking to him are the SENATOR, the AGENT, and an attractive, if fatuous GIRL. I'll check it in the morning, Low - thanks.

question: Sure, columnists can't get along without us. Only our good and great friend, J.J., forgets to mention that. We furnish him with items -
answer: What, some cheap, gruesome gags?

question: You print them, don't you?
answer: Yes, with your clients' names attached. That's the only reason those poor slobs pay you - to see their names in my column all over the world! Now, as I make it out, you're doing ME a favor!

question: I didn't say that, J.J.
answer: The day that I can't get along without press agents' handouts, I'll close up shop, lock, stock and barrel and move to Alaska. Look, Manny, you rode in here on the Senator's shirt tails, so shut your mouth!

question: The day that I can't get along without press agents' handouts, I'll close up shop, lock, stock and barrel and move to Alaska. Look, Manny, you rode in here on the Senator's shirt tails, so shut your mouth!
answer: Now, come, J.J., that's a little too harsh. Anyone seems fair game for you tonight.

question: This man is not for you, Harvey, and you shouldn't be seen with him in public. Because that's another part of a press agents life - he digs up scandal among prominent men and shovels it thin among the columnists who give him space.
answer: He finds Hunsecker's manner disturbing, but addresses him frontally. There is some allusion here that escapes me...

question: We're friends, Harvey - we go as far back as when you were a fresh kid Congressman, don't we?
answer: Why does everything you say sound like a threat?

question: Hello, Harry.
answer: Bonna sera, commendatore. Come sta?

question: You see, Sidalee, that shows that Lt. Kello likes your people.
answer: It's my Brooklyn background, J.J. I'm good on Yiddish, too.

question: Harry, am I supposed to say "uncle"? Anything fit to print, tonight? Hello, Phil. How're the kids. Any news fit to print tonight?
answer: I just checked "downtown". Quiet everywhere tonight.

question: Incidentally, what happened to that doll? - You gave me the item last night. Still alive?
answer: Yeah. At Bellevue. Still hanging on. But they still don't know if she was pushed.

question: I call him the boy with the ice cream face!
answer: Say, that's good - it's nice - in fact, it's APT, Harry!

question: Yeah, I got eyes. I put things together.
answer: I remember ONCE when you didn't quite "put things together". Boy! Was the Mayor mad!

question: Citizens committees! I didn't mean to hit the boy that hard. Yeah, that's when a feller needed a friend and I won't forget his initials, J.J.
answer: That's show business. Thanks, Phil. See you.

question: Spahish...that must show he likes "spigs", too.
answer: I like Harry, but I can't deny he sweats a little. I love this dirty town. Conjugate me a verb, Sidney. For instance, TO PROMISE! You told me you'd break up that romance - when?

question: You want something done, J.J., but I doubt if you yourself know what's involved.
answer: I'm a schoolboy - teach me, teach me.

question: Why not break it up yourself? You could do it in two minutes flat.
answer: At this late date you need explanations...? Susie's all I got - now that she's growing up, I want my relationship with her to stay at least at par! I don't intend to antagonize her if I don't have to. Now, be warned, son - I'll have to blitz you...

question: Frankly, J.J., I don't think you got the cards to blitz me.
answer: I don't?

question: Correct me if I'm wrong, but I don't think so...
answer: I'll listen one more minute.

question: About a year ago, you asked me to do a favor. It was a thing - well, I never did a thing that dirty in all my life. Awright, that brings us up to five weeks ago. "Sidney, I got a nasty little problem here." Did I say no? I'm frank to admit - it don't jell as fast as we like... But all of a sudden I CAN'T GET YOU ON THE PHONE NO MORE! WHY?... And why, as of this date, am I frozen out of the column...
answer: Are you finished?

question: No, lemme finish. I DON'T LIKE THIS JOB! That boy is dumb only on matinee days - otherwise he's got a head. And Susan, like you said, she's growing up. Two heads. What I mean, we got a slippery, dangerous problem here!
answer: Not "we", Sidney, you!

question: Correct me if I'm wrong - WE! Because when I'm out on this very slippery limb for you, you have to know what's involved.
answer: Ha! My right hand hasn't seen my left hand for thirty years!

question: I'll do it, J.J. - don't get me wrong - in for a penny, in for a pound. I'll see it through, but stop beating me around the head. Let me make a living!
answer: What you promised - do it! Don't finagle around. It's later than you think.

question: Excuse it, but it's later than you think. That boy proposed tonight.
answer: Hunsecker is HIT Susie told you that...? No wonder you've been so 'feisty' tonight. Can you deliver?

question: Uh huh.
answer: When?

question: Tonight. Before you go to bed. The cat is in the bag and the bag is in the river.
answer: Expressionless, he examines Sidney. Then he walks off toward the car. He tips the attendant, who thanks him, but instead of getting into the back of the car, he makes a small authoritative gesture to Nikko to move over so that Hunsecker himself may drive. While Nikko does so, Hunsecker turns back to Sidney, whom the CAMERA now includes. Don't be a two time loser, Sidalee. The sentence could be severe...

question: He is satisfied.
answer: Hunsecker gets into the driver's seat beside Nikko, the Japanese houseboy. CAMERA is CLOSE on Hunsecker who does not look back but is clearly aware of the position of Sidney as he puts the car into gear, revving the engine...

question: Who told you about it?
answer: Sidney smiles at Bartha, but the threat is clear. The cigarettes girl...Rita. And she took out all her hairpins, too. I never had the pleasure of meeting your wife. You know what I wonder, Leo? Could you use a hot little item for tomorrow's column?

question: What is this, blackmail? Beat it!
answer: Sidney's face tightens. After a pause, he makes a decision and walks towards the booth. Leo, I've never had the pleasure of meeting your wife...

question: How do you do, Mr. Falco. If you know anything about horses, sit a minute. Help yourself to a glass of this N.Y. State champagne - that's what my husband buys me.
answer: All the imported wines aren't what they're cracked up to be.

question: Whose side are you on, Mr. Falco, his or mine?
answer: Frankly, Mrs. Bartha, I'm a neutral observer for the United Nations.

question: Mrs. Bartha laughs, enjoying his deftness; then: What's your first name?
answer: Sidney.

question: No horse running tomorrow by that name...
answer: You ought to stop this nonsense, Loretta, these two dollar bets.

question: It's compensation, Leo, for the marginal life we lead. Sidney, did you hear the story about the cloak-and-suitor who -- ?
answer: That's right! Tell him, so I can read it in Hunsecker's column first!

question: Hitler!
answer: Just in case you'd like to print it, Leo. It's a blind - no names mentioned. But for your private information, the guy's name is Dallas.

question: There isn't a single name here that gives off vibrations...
answer: Anything there with a name like "cigarette girl"?

question: Where are we running? What am I missing here?
answer: Waiter, the check. This man is trying to hold a gun to my head!

question: That's the horse! Shotgun - Shotgun in the fifth!
answer: What do you want to tell my wife, Sidney...?

question: She is brushing her lap with her napkin. He wants to tell me that you poured champagne all over my lap.
answer: Go on, tell her, I'm waiting!

question: He glances unhappily at his wife. Lorry, I can't let this man blackmail me...
answer: Blackmail...?

question: He wants me to print a dirty smear item for keeping his mouth shut
answer: About what?

question: How is dear old J.J. by the way?
answer: Call him up and ask - he might drop dead with shock.

question: If it were that easy, you wouldn't find an empty phone booth for the next two hours...
answer: A CLOSE SHOT. While Elwell continues, he is not looking at Sidney. Elwell's expression of dislike of Hunsecker is not overemphatic; but Sidney senses, nevertheless, that it is very real - and this gives him a new idea.

question: This is how much I'm washed with Look, Otis, I make no brief for my bilious private life, but he's got the morals of a guinea pig and the scruples of a gangster.
answer: A fine, fat dirty item. Who's it about?

question: A kid named Dallas, who runs a dinky jazz quintet. He keeps company with J.J.'s screwball sister...
answer: This does get a reaction, a flicker of genuine interest. Elwell reads the item for a second time.

question: It's a real goody if, like me, you wanna clobber J.J.! He's got his TV tomorrow. He'd read it just before rehearsals.
answer: Mmm. Trouble is I can't think of any good reason why I should print anything you give me. I can't even think of a bad reason.

question: Sidney drops his eyes to the magazine once more. He fingers it in a preoccupied but significant way. Suppose I introduce you to a lovely reason, Otis. One that's good and bad...and available?
answer: His eyes go from the magazine to Sidney; he gets the point alright. I'm not an unreasonable man...

question: Don't you know who that man is?
answer: Yeah. Otis Elwell. The columnist.

question: Yeah!
answer: And he's a perfect stranger to me.

question: So take five minutes! Get acquainted! He's an important man - he's lonely - don't be dumb!
answer: What do you want all of a sudden - Lady Godiva...? Where's my other shoe?

question: What kind of an act is this?
answer: Don't you think I have any feelings? What am I? A bowl of fruit? A tangerine that peels in a minute?

question: I beg your pardon! I turn myself inside out to help you and now I'm a heavy. Here's your shoe, there's your coat, that's the door!
answer: Sidney...I...I don't do this sort of thing...

question: What sort of thing?
answer: This sort of thing!

question: Listen, you need him for a favor, don't you! And so do I! I need his column--tonight. Didn't you ask me to do something about your job? Don't you have a kid in Military School?
answer: You're a snake, Falco. You're a louse, a real louse.

question: Honey - he's going to help you! You want to lose your job?
answer: A girl needs a little romancing before she -

question: Next time I'll call in a guy to paint silver stars on the ceiling!
answer: What would you think of me if -

question: Nothing I didn't think of you before.
answer: - that's what I mean!

question: Gimme The Record.
answer: I have no power to retract, Mr. Cummings... I'm only Mr. Hunsecker's secretary. No. Nor can I agree that can retraction is necessary. Thank you for calling. I'll get the boss to sign them. You've said that six times - that's why I'm smiling.

question: Hello, Mary, me darlin' and phwat are ye up to today?
answer: That's a question I usually like to ask YOU. Your secretary phoned.

question: What about?
answer: Something about a Frank D'Angelo trying to reach you... Is that the man who manages Susie's boyfriend? Have you seen this? In Otis Elwell's column. "The dreamy marijuana smoke of a lad who heads a highbrow jazz quintet is giving an inelegant odor to that elegant East Side Club where he works. That's no way for a card-holding Party Member to act. Moscow won't like, you naughty boy!"

question: Sally? I got the message. If D'Angelo calls again, tell him I'll be at the office around noon.
answer: Could this be that boy?

question: Dallas? Could be. He doesn't look like a reefer smoker...
answer: If this is true, J.J.'s going to hit the ceiling...

question: Can it be news to you that J.J.'s ceiling needs a plaster job every six weeks?
answer: Sidney, you know that J.J. doesn't like people to look at the column proof in advance...

question: Mary, I'm not "people" - there's Falco blood, sweat and tears in that column. How about dinner tonight?
answer: Bribing me again?

question: And why should I bribe the woman who holds most of my heart?
answer: You're a real rascal, Sidney. I'd certainly dislike you if I didn't like you. You're an amusing boy, but there isn't a drop of respect in you for anything alive - you're too immersed in the theology of making a fast buck. Not that I don't sometimes feel that you yearn for something better...

question: Mary, don't try to sell me the Brooklyn Bridge. I happen to know it belongs to the Dodgers.
answer: I don't mind you looking at the proof of the column in advance, as long as J.J. doesn't know. But don't do it like a boy stealing gum from a slot machine.

question: Who put this item in about the comic? "If there's a more hilarious funny man around than Herbie Temple at the Palace, you'll have to pardon us for not catching the name. We were too busy screaming." Does this Temple have a press agent?
answer: No. It's one of J.J.'s occasional beau gestes. Evidently the fellow's funny, so he gave him a plug.

question: What's your favorite ribbon to go around your favorite chocolates?
answer: Let's wait till Christmas - it's more legitimate then.

question: Herbit Temple here yet? I'm in, Sonny Boy!
answer: I didn't waste words, Herbie, take my word. I says, "look, Figo, I'm not selling you a dozen eggs, I'm selling you HERBIE TEMPLE", I says, so don't gimme your lip!

question: Hiya, Al!
answer: Since when did you two get acquainted?

question: How do you do, Mr. Temple...
answer: Delighted.

question: You watch him, Al, I s...s...stutter!
answer: Temple, I caught your act the other night and -

question: Did you now? On which bounce?
answer: - and I just had to drop by and tell you how great I thought you were.

question: Yeah, if you got a pencil there I'll suggest a word or two. Uh...uh... If there's a funnier man in the world than Herbie Temple at the Palace...uh...pardon us for not catching the name, we were too busy laughing. No, make that 'screaming'. It's sweet of you, J.J., thanks. Probably see you at Twenty One tonight. No, for supper, late. Right. 'Bye...
answer: Speak to this lad, Al, ... to Mr. Falco.

question: See me in my office.
answer: Wait a minute. Speak to him, Al. Al makes all my deals.

question: I don't like a guy that's quick with the hands. Temple, you've been three passes behind for twenty years. This could start you off big - T.V. and anywhere.
answer: And it would cost a pretty penny, huh?

question: Why me...?
answer: Why not you?

question: That's your idea of logic? I tell the Judge I didn't murder the man - the Judge says, "Why not you?"
answer: Only two men in this town could be responsible for that smear - you or Hunsecker or both.

question: Dallas, ask your own manager - he's standing here like a pained wolfhound - Hunsecker and Elwell are enemies to the knife. So how do you get him doing J.J. a favor?
answer: It is a favor, isn't it?

question: Nikko, is Mr. Hunsecker there? This is Mr. Falco. Well, have him call me as soon as he can. It's important. Did you send my folks in Philly the check...?
answer: Yes.

question: I put a lotta trust in you, Chickie...
answer: I know you do, Sidney.

question: Don't judge a situation where you don't know what's involved...
answer: I'm not judging... I swear, Sidney, I can't help it - sometimes I wonder what I see in you...

question: That's no way to talk...
answer: Or what you see in me, for that matter...

question: Stay down town tonight. Maybe we'll take in a show, etc.
answer: If you want me to -

question: The table can wait. No calls. I have to think about my TV show. Did you put the bread out on the terrace for the birds? Susie! Come in a minute, dear... Susie, you're very much in my thoughts today.
answer: Why?

question: What a question, dear, with that newspaper in your hand...
answer: Did Sidney tell you about it?

question: Yes, he phoned. I don't know this boy too well. Anything in these charges? Not being partial, are you?
answer: No, I'm not. I'm not!

question: Susie, take it easy. I'll trust your judgment - you don't have to protest with me. Why are you trembling, dear...?
answer: History repeats itself. Everything that happened to Alan Leslie...began with a smear like this...

question: Yes...
answer: It's just as if I've seen a ghost today...

question: But that wasn't your fault, dear, what happened to Leslie. I've told you that a million times...
answer: Then whose fault was it, J.J.? It was someone's fault, wasn't it?

question: I wouldn't have called the boy exactly balanced...
answer: Alan was not...unbalanced when I married him. And he was not...'indifferent to women' no matter what they said!

question: I'm not fighting with you, puss...
answer: He never would have killed himself if I hadn't gone through with the annulment. Don't you see that made all the rumors seem true? I should have stood up for him...not run out.

question: Then maybe you can tell me if he's as solid as you say, why does he rap me every chance he gets?
answer: Sidney is a liar!

question: Who said Sidney?
answer: I said Sidney!...

question: You know, dear, we're drifting apart, you and I, and I don't like that.
answer: I thought we were talking about Sidney?

question: Let me finish, dear. You had your say, now let me have mine...
answer: I haven't said anything yet, J.J., but if -

question: I started to say we're drifting apart. A year ago, in your wildest dreams, would you have walked by that door without taking up this situation with me? Today I had to call you in!
answer: I'm taking up the situation with you now...

question: Susie, I want to help you--, there's nothing I won't do for you. You're all I've got in the whole, wide world. Well, what have I got? Alimony to a pair of tramps? They're of no concern to me. It's you who count, but don't get me wrong - I don't intend to let you break your neck again!
answer: J.J., you said you want to help me - prove it!

question: How?
answer: Get Steve back his job...please...

question: He means that much to you...?
answer: Yes. With your "prestige" it only takes a minute - ten cents worth of American Tel and Tel.

question: You're picking up my lingo, hon.
answer: I read your column every day...

question: Susie, I like this new attitude of yours. You're growing up and I like it! I don't like it when you're limp and dependent, when you're odd and wayward. This gives you a chance for real survival in a very lousy world. Because, don't forget, dear, you won't always have me with you, will you...?
answer: No, I won't...

question: This Dallas boy must be good for you. Why not bring him around today, before the show? This time I'll clean my glasses for a better look.
answer: I'm not sure I can reach him in time.

question: "From Washington through to Jefferson, from Lincoln and F.D.R. right up to today - the Democratic Way of Life! That's what the man said! Nowadays it doesn't export to well... But you know...and I know...that our best secret weapon is D-E-M-O-
answer: Sidney lingers beside the old movie star who is listening, rapt, to Hunsecker's words. Sidney is less impressed with J.J.'s eloquence. At the conclusion, Mildred applauds lightly. She stands up and moves towards J.J. J.J. wants to talk to Sidney but is frustrated by the old movie star.

question: Of course, Mildred. Of course. You look fine. Mary, help Miss Tam - anything she wants; she's our star today.
answer: A TRACKING SHOT. Sidney comes up beside Hunsecker, falls into step beside him. As they cross towards a water cooler at the back of the stage, they talk in rapid undertone.

question: I got that boy coming over here. What's so funny?
answer: With a pocket fulla firecrackers - good.

question: I think you loused this up but good. If I can trust my eyes, and I think I can, Susie knows all about your dirty work.
answer: Can't hurt...

question: Can't hurt? I had to get him back his job.
answer: I like that, too. Look, J.J., we can wrap this up in one neat bundle, addressed to the dumps - to oblivion. We're going great, but please play it my way. I cased this kid. Know his ins and outs...He's fulla juice and vinegar, just begging for some big shot like you to give him a squeeze. Do little Sidney a favor

question: But it's too late. I got him back the job...
answer: No, that's the point - he won't accept your favor! The manager yes, but not the boy.

question: Well he's got her in a tizzy, I'll tell you that!
answer: Sure, he steams her up - wants her to stand on her own two feet and all that jazz!

question: And who's feet is she on now?
answer: Presumably yours... That's according to St. Dallas.

question: What's this boy got that Susie likes?
answer: Integrity - acute, like indigestion.

question: What does that mean - integrity?
answer: A pocket fulla firecrackers - looking for a match! It's a new wrinkle to tell the truth... I never thought I'd make a killing on some guy's "integrity".

question: Full of beans, ain't you? But you know that you'll stand or fall by what you're doing now...
answer: Calculated risk. Only we happen to know, J.J., that you like me. I'm your star pupil -- I reflect back to you your own talent.

question: I still think he's responsible for the smear.
answer: Not that I'm convinced, but you'll never prove it in a million years. Steve, you'll do what you want, but it can't hurt; he offers you an olive branch - so today like olives!

question: I guess you're right, but -
answer: D'Angelo studies the boy with a paternal affection. Steve, sometimes it's better not to look at your own honesty; but to look the other man in the face. Not because you're my meal ticket - which you are - but because I like you and the boys, please take my advice

question: Well, son, looks like you went out and bought yourself a packet of trouble...
answer: You've been very kind about it, Mr. Hunsecker.

question: Give Susie credit for that. I took her word that there was nothing to the smear. Matter of fact, I'll have my say about smears on the show today. That's why I'd like YOUR personal assurance, too.
answer: Mr. Hunsecker, there's nothing to that smear. You have my sincere word...

question: Does he have to be here in our hair?
answer: Why, has he bothered you before?

question: Is it news to you?
answer: Son, lots of people tell me I'm a gifted man, but I still can't see around corners. Just exactly what are you so hot about? I mean, I know it's a difficult thing to be an artist in this crudest of possible worlds, but --

question: Nuts! I'm not here as an artist! I'm here as an average Joe, who happens to love your sister Susie!
answer: Well, just be careful you don't knock her down, huh? Frankly, son, you lost me on that last hill. Just give us the punch line...

question: No punch line. Maybe I was just admiring your know-how---yours and Falco's.
answer: Why do you keep coupling me with Falco?

question: How did you mean it...? Both of you keep quiet! You've made more damage here in one minute than a plague of locusts! If you're tired, Susie, sit down--- this needs investigation! How did you mean it...? Come on, let's go! Let's go!...
answer: I don't take kindly to you and Falco selling me ethics. Who's the injured party here, you?

question: Right now you're in no position to ask questions! And your snide remarks---
answer: Wait a minute, I haven't handed over punishing privileges to you YET! Put the whip down and I might respect what you're saying...

question: Susie, as always, is free to say anything she thinks. Go on, dear, say exactly what's on your mind, dear.
answer: Those "dears" sound like daggers. May I suggest that you stop DARING her to speak?

question: May I lift my eyebrows? What is this? What are you trying to do?
answer: I'm trying to get Susie to stand up to you. But your manner is so threatening that she's afraid to speak!

question: Son, you raise your voice again and you'll be outa here on your golden pratt!
answer: Suddenly Susan lets loose, with restrained nervous energy; she is near to tears. Steve, if only for my sake, I want this stopped! And the same goes for you, too, J.J.!

question: He interjects. Susie, I'm sorry if---
answer: Sometimes I think ALL men are fools!...

question: You see, Dallas, a plague on both our houses... We may have to call this game on account of darkness... If looks could kill, I'm dead...
answer: No, I don't care about you -- you're fantastic. My whole interest, if it's not too late, is in Susie...and how to undo what you've done to her...

question: And what have I done to her, besides not buy her a new fur coat lately? Sidney, you were right -- the boy's a dilly.
answer: Why? Because I don't like the way you toy with human lives? - Your contempt and malice? Because I won't be the accomplice of your sick ego - and the way it's crippled Susie...? You think of yourself - you and your column - you see yourself as a national glory...but to me, and thousands of others like me, you and your slimy scandal, your phony patriotics - to me, Mr. Hunsecker, you are a national disgrace!

question: Son, I don't fancy shooting mosquitoes with elephant guns. So suppose you just shuffle along and call it a day...
answer: But my day with Susie isn't over yet and--

question: There is some emotion in his face as he looks towards the girl. More gently, he moves forward past CAMERA...
answer: Sensing the approach of Hunsecker behind her, she moves away again; she is still crying, but is trying to recover. Presently Hunsecker approaches her again. He speaks very gently, soothingly, comforting...

question: You in a mood, Susie, to run over to Milgrim's later and buy a few new frocks?
answer: No. I'm going home.

question: Want Sidney to drive you over? Drive Susie home. Again we see some emotion in his face as he studies the girl. His eyes flick towards the stage behind him where Sidney stands watching. He moves gently forward and then speaks in a quiet voice which reveals how desperately he needs her reassurance: Susie...I...I'd have to take it very much amiss if you ever saw that boy again.
answer: After a pause, she turns towards him; she looks him straight in the face. I'll never see him again.

question: Nursing the injury to his hand, he looks after the disappearing taxi. As he recovers from the pain, his expression slowly changes to one of thoughtful appraisal.
answer: So that's what "integrity" looks like. Well, I'm always willing to learn... How is that slob, D'Angelo, your uncle?

question: My mother's side--her brother. That reminds me, J.J., Susie looks run down. She can stand a vacation and so can you. People say, "Oh, the great J.J., he's made of iron!", but you can use a rest, guy.
answer: What are you so chipper about? If I put a cross on every one of your mistakes, you'd look like a graveyard!

question: But not for anything I did today...
answer: Sidney, I know human nature. Susie lied to me - she'll see that boy again.

question: You're right, J.J. - she won't give him up, but it doesn't matter. Because the real "money ball" is the boy, not Susan. And if --
answer: These drinks are warm. What are you a critic? Forget it. The real money ball is the boy...

question: Yeah, the boy...we're on the verge of a farce, a real farce. As I see it, if Susie had stood behind him today he might have proved a threat. But since primarily he's wedded to his work, he's not going to be able to take it.
answer: Stop tinkering, pal - that horse radish won't jump a fence!

question: In brief, J.J., it's all over because any hour now the boy will give her up. Is it a farce or not?
answer: This syrup you're giving out, Sidney, you pour over waffles, not J.J. Hunsecker! What do you mean that lousy kid will give up my sister?

question: Are you listening?
answer: How does it matter who's sister? The main thing, they're through and -

question: From Sidney's viewpoint. Without turning, Hunsecker interrupts: Am I supposed to forget how that boy talked to me today?
answer: J.J., is he worthy of a second glance from a man like you? Is he, I mean?...

question: From Sidney's viewpoint. Pausing during the process of eating, Hunsecker reaches into an inside pocket. Brief epitaph
answer: Steamship tickets?

question: For the next sailing of the Mary. Susan's run down - she's never been abroad and as you so cogently put it, I'm not made of iron.
answer: That's good. Now that louse is outa Susie's hair for good. He has an instinct to laugh; but something tells him not to.

question: J.J., it's one thing to wear your dog collar...but when it gets to be a noose...I'd rather have my freedom.
answer: The man in jail is always for freedom.

question: Except, if you'll excuse me, I'm not in jail.
answer: From Sidney's viewpoint. Sure you're in jail, Sidney. You're a prisoner of your own fears, of your own greed and ambition; you're in jail.

question: From Hunsecker's viewpoint. J.J. If you're trying to -
answer: You, little boy, don't know who you are! Talking around corners with the big shots, ten dollar dinners - fourteen suits and cashmere coats - you tell yourself THAT'S who you are! Later you won't know who you are without a penthouse on upper Park! But underneath it all, ratting around from day to day, you DO know who you are! You're a fearful, ignorant nobody - a poor wop kid from the slums of Philly - hoping nobody else finds it out!

question: A CLOSE UP. He knows the truth of what is said. But he takes refuge in quiet retaliation: A little hunch occurs to me - you have just painted a self-portrait. You know who YOU are because you scare people - that's what you've got against this boy. He -
answer: Hunsecker is prepared to give it out, but not take it. I told you what I want you to do tonight!

question: He looks down on Hunsecker, leans over the table. You're blind, Mr. Magoo. This is a crossroads for me. I won't get Kello. Not for a life-time pass to the Polo Grounds. Not if you serve me Ingrid Bergman on a plate.
answer: Sidney, I told you -

question: J.J., I swear to you on my mother's life, I won't do it. If you gave me your COLUMN I wouldn't do a thing like that... We see that an idea has entered his head - an idea that takes the wind out of his indignation. His eyes lift rapidly to Hunsecker's face.
answer: And who do you think writes the column while Susie and I are away for three months?...

question: She'll be down in a minute.
answer: What does she wanna see you about?

question: She didn't say.
answer: I could think of better places to meet her, instead of here. He lives on the whole top floor.

question: I doubt that it matters any more.
answer: He addresses Steve soberly. Steve. You made a very dangerous enemy of him today. Matter of fact, I'm very glad we got the tour ahead. If I'm any judge, you hurt him today where he lives... He won't forget it and he won't forgive...

question: Sure. We're on our way to Robard's for a benefit. I've only got five minutes... Just two cups of java. Make it moke.
answer: Steve...what you tried to do today...you tried to take me up on a high mountain...I couldn't go all the way...I failed you... Will you forgive me? Have I lost you, Steve? Have I...?

question: Well, maybe I was wrong, too... But there's no doubt, Susie, that we have to face some serious things...
answer: No one's ever stood up to my brother the way you did.

question: But you didn't do much about it, Susie. You walked out, and there I was...solo...and not too good at that.
answer: I just didn't think that I could antagonize him, Steve -- for OUR sake, I mean.

question: Susie, I was there for OUR sake, too. But what a world it would be if we were all afraid to learn to walk and talk because it might offend poppa! By the way, I think your brother was completely responsible for the smears...
answer: This accusation is made lightly, in passing. But Susan reacts to it, trying to interject: Steve, I...

question: But I don't care about that now. He knew what he was doing today. He was laying down the conditions under which he MIGHT consent to our marriage - if I would bend to every whim of his, like Sidney! I couldn't do that, Susie...
answer: After a pause, she says: You're saying goodbye, aren't you?

question: No! I'm saying that for your sake you have to make a clean break with your brother!
answer: But, please, Steve, please - one step at a time! I was born only yesterday!...

question: This beautiful coat is more than just a coat... I hate it! It's a mink straight-jacket!
answer: Steve, I feel exhausted...what do you want me to do?

question: Not what you're doing now. At least don't ask me - don't ask him. You're fighting for your life! What do YOU want to do?
answer: You are saying goodbye, aren't you...?

question: He reacts vigorously, protesting: That's fish four days old...! I can't buy it, Susie! Right out of that mouth I love, like you're a ventriloquist's dummy, your BROTHER is saying goodbye! Gee!...you want me to be honest, don't you?!
answer: A despairing cry: No, Steve, I don't. I don't. Not if it KILLS me I don't!... Let's not talk any more...you have to go... Goodbye, Mr. D'Angelo. Take care of Steve.

question: What's all the rush? You said three o'clock.
answer: He's leaving early. After this "set". He'll be out in a couple of minutes... Can't you wait up the block? It's not going to look so good, right in front of the club...

question: It's nice, Sidney, that you give me this tip...
answer: - He's got them on him.

question: ...And he's got them on him. I appreciate a thing like that - I appreciate where you are looking out for the virtue of the city. What's your hurry, Snooks?
answer: Take your hands off, Kello...

question: Murph, how do you like this face? Why, I'll be darned -- it's melting! Something got you scared, Sidney...? Listen, rectify me a certain thing. Wasn't you kidding, Snooks, when you told J.J. I was fat...?
answer: Sleep in peace, Kello -- you're skinny -- but J.J. says you sweat!

question: Is that a fact? He's a dilly, ain't he? By the by, what did he have against this boy?
answer: He goes out with girls.

question: Well, I'll be darned. And what does J.J. think he SHOULD do?
answer: Go out with DIFFERENT girls!

question: He moves forward a little. I get the peculiar impression, Snooks, that you don't like me. Could I be wrong?
answer: He turns swiftly and goes up the stairs out of Kello's reach. You could be right, you fat slob?

question: He turns to look back towards the direction in which the Police Car has departed. He seems unable to comprehend what he has heard; but a slow and terrible fear is dawning on him... I'm looking for your brother. Is he home?
answer: No. Mr. D'Angelo - is something wrong?

question: When does he usually gets in, your night-owl brother?
answer: Seldom before five. What's the matter? Would you care to come in a minute?

question: No...no. Thanks.
answer: Something's happened. To Steve.

question: He's in the hospital...He's under arrest, too... They planted reefer cigarettes on him...in his overcoat pocket.
answer: Where is he...I want to go to him...

question: Miss Hunsecker, if you see him again they might...might kill him.
answer: Who is "they"?

question: Susie, if I get your meaning, you're pitching very wild balls. What -
answer: Don't bother to lie, Sidney. I don't care anymore.

question: Listen, get a good night's sleep - tomorrow's another day. Feeling sorry for yourself won't help.
answer: I'm sorry about Steve, not myself. I'm even sorry for my brother. To be so lonely, without one real friend in the world - to have to hang on to a worthless rag of a girl like me because she's his only real family -

question: Come on now, chickie, why don't you go to bed...?
answer: And I'm sorry for you, too, Sidney. You're going down with the ship.

question: What ship?
answer: THIS ship. Don't you know how my brother will see you after tonight? You'll be the man who drove his little stainless sister to suicide...

question: It's late and I'm going home... He can't go. Probably, she's bluffing. But he can't be certain. He is suddenly angry. Susie, whatever problems you have with J.J. - I didn't invent them! What're you blaming me for? If you learned to let out your hatred you would be better off!
answer: Like you?

question: Yeah! Like me! I don't choke on my own gall - I fight back! Let THEM choke, not me!
answer: I'm not a man, Sidney, I'm -

question: I know that bit - you're a girl; you need a man to give you strength! So what do you pick such weak sisters for? Don't you know yet that you fight fire with fire, not with tear drops?
answer: I could almost forgive you if what you did to Steve came from jealousy and love...

question: I didn't do anything!
answer: ...but you did it for greed, Sidney - and that's pathetic.

question: Don't run away - I was always the man for you! I'm talking to you out of two years of silence - listen to what I say! Inside of six months -
answer: Please, Sidney, I can't stand this -

question: Another crisis past. She'll be fast asleep in five minutes, loaded with those headache pills...
answer: Sidney seems not to hear this remark. He is concentrated on the door; he moves hesitantly towards it, apprehensive. CAMERA includes Hunsecker in background.

question: Now we'll get to you, Sidney. As far as the column is concerned - tonight you have forfeited every ethical consideration I ever felt for you...
answer: Look, J.J., I'll grant you anything you want. Susie's off her rocker tonight! Go in and see what she's doing! Go in and talk to her quietly - unless you want a corpse!

question: GET OUT OF THIS HOUSE!
answer: Susie, YOU get out of this house! - Get out before it's too late! Sidney has gone too far now to pull back. Inevitably, he continues. During the speech, CAMERA PULLS BACK to include Susan and then Hunsecker. Listen with care - this will cost me everything, so you know I'm telling you the truth!

question: You're incapable of the truth...
answer: Susie, there's nothing wrong with Dallas! Your brother and I arranged it all. And if the Leslie boy is still a squooshy item in your life, forget it! - your brother arranged that one, too! I don't usually give away presents; but this is my gift to you
